question: A 48-year-old male client is admitted to the emergency department after a flash fire at a shipyard. The nurse performs a primary survey and assesses the extent of the client's burns. The assessment reveals partial and full-thickness burns covering the entire anterior trunk, the full circumference of the right arm, the anterior surface of the left arm, the genitalia, and the posterior surface of the right leg. The client's back has scattered areas of erythema without blistering. Based on these findings, which areas should the nurse include when calculating the total body surface area (TBSA) percentage for fluid resuscitation? Select all that apply.

options.label: Full circumference of the right arm
Anterior surface of the left arm
Posterior surface of the right leg
Anterior surface of the right leg

answerBreakdown.title: TBSA Calculation Rationale
answerBreakdown.calculationSummary: The total body surface area (TBSA) is calculated using the Rule of Nines for adults. This calculation is critical for determining fluid resuscitation needs. TBSA calculation only includes partial-thickness (second-degree) and full-thickness (third-degree) burns. Superficial (first-degree) burns are excluded.

options.label: Full circumference of the right arm
options.rationale: Correct. The assessment identifies partial and full-thickness burns to the full circumference of the right arm. According to the Rule of Nines, a full arm accounts for 9% of the TBSA.

options.label: Entire anterior trunk
options.rationale: Correct. The assessment notes burns to the entire anterior trunk. The Rule of Nines allocates 18% of the TBSA to the anterior trunk.

options.label: Anterior surface of the left arm
options.rationale: Correct. The client has burns on the anterior surface of the left arm. This represents half of the total arm surface area, which is calculated as 4.5% of the TBSA.

options.label: Posterior surface of the right leg
options.rationale: Correct. The scenario specifies burns to the posterior surface of the right leg. The posterior aspect of one leg accounts for 9% of the TBSA.

options.label: Genitalia
options.rationale: Correct. The assessment indicates burns to the genitalia. This area is allocated 1% of the TBSA in the Rule of Nines.

options.label: Scattered erythema on the back
options.rationale: Incorrect. Erythema without blistering indicates a superficial (first-degree) burn. Superficial burns are not included in the TBSA calculation used for determining fluid resuscitation volumes because the skin barrier remains intact and significant fluid shifts do not occur.

options.label: Anterior surface of the right leg
options.rationale: Incorrect. The nurse must analyze cues precisely. The assessment findings specifically state that the *posterior* surface of the right leg was burned, not the anterior surface. Including unburned areas would lead to an inaccurate TBSA and incorrect fluid resuscitation.
